source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_034_chunk3
evidence_span: The thin oxide layers on both Zircaloy-4 materials consisted of dense layers of well-ordered columnar grains.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_034_chunk3
evidence_span: No difference in grain size was observed at different distances from the interface.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_034_chunk3
evidence_span: The oxide layers contained a fairly high amount of twin grain boundaries

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_034_chunk3

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_034_chunk3
evidence_span: the columns were oriented perpendicular to the oxide-metal interface.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_034_chunk3
evidence_span: SEM examinations showed a smooth growth front even in this oxide-metal interface.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_034_chunk3
evidence_span: In TEM, we observed columnar grains of approximately the same size and appearance as in the interface after three days

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_034_chunk3
evidence_span: no porosity between grains and no amorphous layer was present.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_034_chunk3
evidence_span: Regions with a high dislocation density in the metal were observed at the interface.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_034_chunk3
evidence_span: In the low-annealed Zircaloy-4, the weight gains after 21 days were already so high (approximately $5 0 0 ~ \mathrm { m g } / \mathrm { d m } ^ { 2 } )$

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_034_chunk3
evidence_span: the interface had a more disordered structure, with short columnar and equiaxed grains growing from the metal, see Fig. 5b.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_034_chunk3
evidence_span: Intergranular pores and cracks were observed very close to the interface.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_034_chunk3
evidence_span: No tetragonal oxide was found in the oxide-metal interface of the two materials.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_034_chunk3
evidence_span: the low-annealed Zircaloy-4 contained regions with a high dislocation density in the metal close to the interface.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_034_chunk3
evidence_span: the growth front was highly uneven as observed by SEM and optical microscope, and large differences in oxide thickness were found between different areas of the coupons.

evidence_span: In the outer part of the oxide layer on standard Zircaloy-4 (Coupon 26, Fig. 6b), the majority of the grains were columnar and monoclinic

evidence_span: a few columnar tetragonal grains and equiaxed monoclinic grains were detected.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_034_chunk3
evidence_span: The oxide was generally dense, with only very fine pores and microcracks between the grains.

evidence_span: In standard Zircaloy-4 that cracks occurred mainly between equiaxed oxide grains.
